No, we're not having a rational discussion/argument...have
we ever, especially when ideology and hidden
unarticulated agendas drive discourse? The nature of this web based back and forth ping pong like discussion makes it very difficult to engage rationally and systematically
with one's opponents when they do not find it in their
interests to do so.

It takes two to sit down in
the same space and interact in real time with
no artificial constraints on time, and engage seriously
with ideas, testable assertions, false interpretations
of data, spurious conclusions, etc. This is not the current paradigm for what it means to have a conversation about complicated issues, and it is difficult to see it ever being so without some out of the box game changing rupture in the underlying acceptance of the perceived rules of the game.

Intellectual rigor and honesty, these are not commonly held values currently in vogue, and it seems impossible to
impose them as part of the rules of the web based
discourse.

The culture itself has no generally accessible outlet for such discussion, which suggests it is not a core universally held value whose
importance needs no justification. This is clearly dangerous, as shown by the types of stresses and
distortions other societies have suffered when they
did not maintain this simple principle. Its absence clearly
limits how this society constructively addresses its basic problems. One wonders if it can even do so any longer...

....Indeed, in an important recent decision concerning a company involved in building the Jerusalem light rail, a high-level French court held that international law does not restrict companies from doing business across the Green Line, or even working on Israeli government-funded projects.

The EU doesn’t apply this standard even to territorial disputes involving European countries. So it can’t really be about international law, since the EU only wants to apply this standard to Israel.

Moreover, the guidelines contain a massive exception that undermines the notion that this is about international law rather than EU foreign policy. Article 15 exempts groups that “promot[e] the Middle East peace process in line with EU policy.” Either the Geneva Conventions and related rules prevent Israelis from having anything to do with the West Bank or they do not – but they certainly do not contain a “things the EU likes” exception. The exemption reveals the true purpose of the rules: to promote European foreign policy, not to vindicate international law. Indeed, the essence of the rule of law is about applying general rules to similar cases, regardless of one’s sympathies. The application of unique rules to Israel is the opposite of lawful.

The federal government and private payors have been obsessing over physician payment for many years and have colluded to successfully fix prices for evaluation and management services at a very low level. Typical physician payment for an office visit of $50-$100 is less than most people pay to have an auto mechanic lift up the hood of a car. Yet these efforts have done nothing to control overall health care costs or health insurance premiums, which are driven by relentlessly rising costs for hospital care, medical devices, durable equipment, and prescription drugs. Not to mention the massive overhead the system pays for administrative costs.

The major effect of price controls on physician services has been to drive more private physician practices into the arms of health systems and hospitals, which operate in a more expensive, more bureaucratic, and less efficient manner. A minority of successful primary care physicians have been able to opt out of Medicare and insurance altogether, delivering more attentive, personalized care to a smaller number of patients, further reducing public access to primary care.

In my own experience, hospital and health system executives are far more profit- and volume-driven than physicians. Reformers are engaging in magical thinking if they believe that “bundled payments” and other trendy schemes which simply shift more power and control to health care executives are going to lead to better or less expensive medical care.
